text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen recently 
I've been making a lot of heavier comfort food

fall winter dishes so I thought it's about time 
we lighten things up a little bit with a salad

so I'm going to use a vegetable that's in season 
right now which is this child a squash to make us
a Thai salad that in Thailand we call tum fakmeaw tum is to pound so this is a pounded salad

like papaya salad and fakmeaw is our term for 
this vegetable here which grows in the northern

part of Thailand where it's colder so it's sort of 
our version of winter salad let's get started so

if you've never cooked with a chayote before it 
is extremely versatile think of it sort of like

a jicama or an apple that's not sweet so it's 
got a firm crunchy texture and we can use it in

stir fries it's great in soups you can put it in 
curries I mean or you can eat it raw like like a

vegetable and dip it's really good subtle subtle 
sweetness and Thailand we also use the leaves as

well for stir frying and whatnot that's the seed 
it's very soft you can just sort of spoon it out

this white bit is okay and to get it into sticks 
like this you just make big slices first and then

take each slice and cut them on a bias and then 
you end up with nice sticks that'll look great

in a salad now in addition to a chayote I'm also 
going to add some apples to it which I have cut

sort of in the same way now in Thailand we also 
use apples a lot in this kind of salad and the

sweetness will pair really well with the lime 
acidic dressing other than that everything is

pretty straightforward so let's start pounding so 
I'm using my special papaya salad mortar here so

the mortars bigger ants made of clay the pencils 
made of wood is a lot lighter so it's for made

specifically for making this kind of salad it's 
also great for just light duty crushing if you

don't have one big like this don't worry you can 
start it out in a smaller mortar and I'll show you

what to do after okay so I'm going to go in with 
some garlic and chilli so standard two ingredients

for a thumb which is this kind of salad just until 
there's no big chunks especially the chilies skin

is fine but no big chunks of chilies I'm going 
to go in with my palm sugar for this I want to

make sure I finely chop it otherwise it'll have 
a hard time dissolving in here if you want you

can quickly dissolve it and make a quick syrup but 
this is fine as well at this point you just want

it to be sort of muddy pasty moist it's not going 
to be completely dissolved that's okay I'm going

to now go in with some dried shrimp now dried 
room you can find at Asian grocery stores usually

in the refrigerated section and if it's large I 
roughly chop it they're like shrimp jerky as a

nice chewy umami flavor so good so just a quick 
pound just to break up the shrimp a little bit

and now I'm going to add something that's a little 
different and that is cashews the butteriness of

cashews work really well with the chayote and 
the apples so already roasted but unsalted and

now I'm going to crush it until the broken into 
small pieces and it'll help thicken the dressing

a little bit make it a little bit more luscious 
small pieces we're not doing cashew butter here

just to break it up so it mixes better I'm going 
to use a spoon to sort of flip the mixture so it's

mixed up a little bit I'm going to add lime juice 
promise me you'll use fresh lime juice if you can

fine line for whatever reason even lemon juice 
would be better than bottled stuff and then fish

sauce squirrel it around just to get it mixed 
up I'm going to add in some tomatoes but I'll

show you a little trick that I do I find that if 
I cut it into regular wedges they're a little too

big so I just do an offset west like this then you 
get smaller pieces and then you get nice sort of

interesting looking pieces now I'm just going 
to dump these in not pounding just squashing a

little bit just to get the juices release just 
a couple times and the juice will come out and

sort of mellow out the acidity of the lime juice 
and become part of the dressing okay at this point

I'm done with the pestle and I'm going to move 
it into a mixing bowl so you guys can see better

and also to show you that if you're working with 
small pestle a small mortar and pestle transfer it

into a large mixing bowl and you can finish your 
salad there okay so that's a a workaround if you

don't have this large mortar so now I'm going in 
with my chayote and also my apples so the apples

I put a little bit of lime juice on it so they 
don't turn brown now the ratio between chayote

and apple up to you if you want more apple let's 
check out they I like to do a little bit more

chayote I find the apple a little bit too sweet 
what I like to add and this happens all the time

in Thailand is people like to add little shreds 
of carrots for sort of pops of color so I've got

this carrot which you can can tell has been used 
for this purpose many times and I've got this cool

julienne peeler that's a Thai brand we use this a 
lot for papaya salad and things and you just great

some shreds right into the bowl and doesn't have 
to be a lot and if you don't have this cool peeler

you can just hand julienne it there that's it and 
now your salad is like a party I'm also going to

add some green onions which is not common but I 
think it works really well with this one so some

chopped up green onions if you've got long beans 
you can also put some long beans there we go now

that look that's looking good I'm gonna give this 
a taste mmm spot-on now I'm going to show you a

little plating trick if you want to make this 
nice and beautiful for your guests so I've got

some apple slices here that I finly thinly slice 
and I've just been soaking them in lime water just

to prevent them from turning brown and I'm going 
to just drain them off real quick and then I get

a plate and I like a dark-colored played because 
it's the salad stands out more you fan this out

as sort of like a bed for your salad and it's 
pretty and it's just a little something special

you know there you go so pretty this looks so good 
it just looks so refreshing and you know this is

a great side dish if you've got something heavy 
and you want like a slaw type thing to go with

it if you were eating pulled pork or barbeque 
oh this would be the perfect accompaniment just

some whole cashews on top so people know there 
is cashews in here and that is it how beautiful

is that now that is guaranteed to impress your 
next guest and all you've done is slice up some

apples and put them on her plate okay let's 
taste it sure I get a cashew mmm crunchy super

refreshing the butteriness of the cashew it just 
helps mellow everything out I love chayote it's

such a versatile vegetables if you've never cooked 
with it I really encourage you to give it a try oh

and it's spicy and it's garlicky it's the perfect 
side dish to really any meal in my opinion but

especially if you're having something rich and 
heavy oh so good so when you make it send me a

photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram and I'll 
include some of them in my monthly newsletter and

the recipe is on hot I teach ENCOM as always and 
if you haven't subscribed to my youtube channel

please through the button is right here and I 
will see you next time for your next delicious

Thai meal and I just soaked them in some lime 
juice water just to prevent them from burning
they will never burn in the lime water
